title: Do cell phone 'Brain Training' games really improve brain function? - Quora

response.answer_text: Brain training games do not improve intelligence. We have, so far, not found any practical means of boosting intelligence. See Haier, R. J. (2017). The Neuroscience of Intelligence, Cambridge University Press for a full discussion. Some businesses have marketed brain training games with the claim that they improve mental performance. Lumosity is one example of a game that was sold for this purpose. The FTC's alleged that Lumos Ads misled customers with false or deceptive advertising, and that the company had failed to disclose that many of its testimonials had been solicited as part of a contest that offered winners prizes such as iPads, lifetime subscriptions to Lumosity, or a free trip to San Francisco. As part of the settlement, Lumos Labs agreed to pay the FTC $50 million but a district court suspended all but $2 million of that amount because the company couldn’t actually afford it.

Let’s look at it from another angle-the point being of not over relying upon only the games by themselves to stimulate, but also to review the overall sets of practices that one’s self is usually observing. Since if there is far too much of something-then there is an imbalance of sorts that is ensuing. That is why, rather than over expecting-first learn to earnestly accept the actuality/reality of what’s already being and how that could be further strengthened ever more remarkably………for then from that/those gradual sets of self awareness will emerge far more unique sets of insights to appropriate identify ever more commendable ways to meritoriously evolve.
